rdf:about="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters-viewer">     <rss:title>Urban Design Matters</rss:title>     <rss:link>https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters-viewer/rss</rss:link>     <rss:description>At The Bartlett urban design is a cross-disciplinary subject, taught, researched and practised across the faculty.</rss:description>     <dc:creator>Brigid C B Marriott</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2014-02-05T13:50:27Z</dc:date>          <rss:items>       <rdf:Seq>          <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/Urban-design-matters-45"/>         <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/urban-design-matters-44"/>         <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/farrell-review-urban-design-matters"/>         <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/urban-design-matters-41-neo-liberal-space"/>       </rdf:Seq>     </rss:items>   </rss:channel>        <rss:item rdf:about="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/Urban-design-matters-45">       <rss:title>45: In support of subversive strategies and crazy ideas</rss:title>       <rss:link>https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/Urban-design-matters-45</rss:link>       <rss:description>In April 2014 the Royal Academy set out an open call for architect-led multidisciplinary teams to put forward bold new ideas for reimagining the area of Mayfair directly to the north of their Burlington Gardens building. \ufffd\ufffdAt the launch of the resulting Reimagining Mayfair pop-up exhibition I had the great pleasure of sitting as part of an \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdexpert\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd panel convened to comment on the short-listed entries. \ufffd\ufffdThe process reminded me both of the very great importance of periodically freeing up our thinking by removing the shackles that bind us to the constraints and realities of the real world, and of the value of the quick and dirty ideas competition as a means to achieve this; giving licence to innovation and creative thinking and to stimulating debate. \ufffd\ufffdIt is an approach that we should utilise more widely.</rss:description>       <dc:subject>The Bartlett, UCL's global faculty of the built environment.</dc:subject>       <dc:creator>Matthew P Carmona</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2015-02-19T19:00:24Z</dc:date>                                 </rss:item>           <rss:item rdf:about="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/urban-design-matters-44">       <rss:title>44: Street smart, understanding our local mixed streets</rss:title>       <rss:link>https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/urban-design-matters-44</rss:link>       <rss:description>As cities expand around the world with investment flowing simultaneously into new suburbs and the revitalisation of city centres, the mixed, often arterial, streets that both connect the parts and which, historically, have been the focus of local public amenities \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd shops, public transport, municipal services, leisure and sports facilities, bars and restaurants, etc. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd have come under increasing pressure.\ufffd\ufffd The twin threats of spiralling traffic growth and concentration of amenities and investment in large accessible and easy to develop central or out-of-town locations undoubtedly contribute to these trends, but they may also be a bi-product of neglect amongst local policy makers, businesses and development and management professionals who don\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt understand such places and their layers of complexity or know how to manage them.\ufffd\ufffd</rss:description>       <dc:subject>The Bartlett, UCL's global faculty of the built environment.</dc:subject>       <dc:creator>Rebecca Spaven</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2014-08-20T10:11:06Z</dc:date>                                 </rss:item>           <rss:item rdf:about="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/Urban-Design-Matters-43">       <rss:title>43: Towards a place (leadership) council for England</rss:title>       <rss:link>https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/Urban-Design-Matters-43</rss:link>       <rss:description>  In the last column in this series I explored The Farrell Review, and the wide ranging proposals it makes to reinvigorate the debate on design and the built environment in England. For me, one of the most intriguing proposals in the report is the call for a Place Leadership Council (PLC) in relation to which Farrell makes a number of concrete proposals:</rss:description>       <dc:subject>The Bartlett, UCL's global faculty of the built environment.</dc:subject>       <dc:creator>Matthew P Carmona</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2014-05-20T10:25:51Z</dc:date>                                 </rss:item>           <rss:item rdf:about="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/farrell-review-urban-design-matters">       <rss:title>42: 'Our future in place' \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd or is it?</rss:title>       <rss:link>https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/farrell-review-urban-design-matters</rss:link>       <rss:description> On coming to power in 2010, Ed Vaizey, a long-term enthusiast for modern architecture, was the UK coalition government\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds first choice as Minister for Architecture. In fact he quickly had to step down from the role when another Minister\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds conflict of interest in the communications portfolio left Vaizey swapping architecture for broadband and the like. Returning to the architecture role in 2012 to find that his predecessor had inexplicably wound up the Commission for Architecture &amp; the Built Environment (CABE) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd an organisation described by some as England\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds answer to a national architecture policy \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Ed Vaizey set about instructing Sir Terry Farrell to lead a review of architecture and design in the built environment. The unwritten aim was to determine what should be done to fill the glaring vacuum that now constitutes English national policy on design in the built environment. The result makes a fascinating read.</rss:description>       <dc:subject>The Bartlett, UCL's global faculty of the built environment.</dc:subject>       <dc:creator>Matthew P Carmona</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2014-04-05T10:12:54Z</dc:date>                                 </rss:item>           <rss:item rdf:about="https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/urban-design-matters-41-neo-liberal-space">       <rss:title>41: Neo-liberal public space, in London (and beyond)</rss:title>       <rss:link>https://www.bartlett.ucl.ac.uk/cross-faculty-initiatives/urban-design/urban-design-matters/urban-design-matters-41-neo-liberal-space</rss:link>       <rss:description>       The period since 2000 and the election of London\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds first city-wide mayor has seen a reinvigorated London-wide governance as an increasingly strong counter-balance to the 33 local boroughs and London\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds powerful development sector.</rss:description>       <dc:subject>The Bartlett, UCL's global faculty of the built environment.</dc:subject>       <dc:creator>Brigid C B Marriott</dc:creator>              <dc:date>2014-02-05T14:39:04Z</dc:date>                                 </rss:item>    </rdf:RDF>
